actualResults.title: Information Disclosure - Endpoint Enumeration Possible via HTTP Status Code Differentiation
actualResults.assessment: Legitimate new discovery - The application returns predictable HTTP 404 for non-existent endpoints while 200 for existing ones, combined with exposed Werkzeug version information (Werkzeug/1.0.1 Python/3.13.3) in Server headers. This is a genuine information disclosure vulnerability enabling endpoint enumeration.

actualResults.title: Insecure Temporary File Handling - Information Disclosure
actualResults.assessment: Legitimate new discovery - The application creates temporary HTML files in the web-accessible static/ directory with world-readable permissions (644) and predictable naming patterns. A TOCTOU race condition window exists between file creation and deletion, potentially allowing unauthorized access to temporary files containing user payloads.

actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers and Explicitly Disabled XSS Protection
actualResults.assessment: Legitimate new discovery - The application explicitly sets X-XSS-Protection: 0 (disabling browser XSS filter) and lacks critical security headers: Content-Security-Policy, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, and Strict-Transport-Security. This creates multiple attack vectors for clickjacking, MIME sniffing, and protocol downgrade.

actualResults.title: Outdated Flask Version with Known Vulnerabilities and Debug Mode Enabled
actualResults.assessment: Legitimate new discovery - The application uses Flask 1.1.4 (EOL since 2019) with Werkzeug 1.0.1, both vulnerable to multiple CVEs including CVE-2021-21501 (Werkzeug debugger PIN bypass). Debug mode is enabled (app.run(debug=True)), exposing the interactive debugger which facilitates RCE and information disclosure.

matched.actualTitle: Reflected XSS Vulnerability with Blacklist Filter Bypass in name Parameter
matched.matchReason: Both findings identify the same vulnerability: XSS in the name parameter of the /xss12 endpoint with a bypassable blacklist filter. The actual finding provides detailed bypass techniques (onerror, ontouchstart, onmousemove, space-insertion) that confirm the expected finding's description of bypassing input filtering to execute arbitrary JavaScript. The impact descriptions align perfectly (arbitrary JavaScript execution, session hijacking, data theft).
